title: Meghan Markle looks like Princess Diana as she wears a bindi on charity visit to India
text:
Meghan Markle looks like Princess Diana as she wears a bindi on charity visit to India Prince Harry's girlfriend visited women in Delhi and Mumbai Share Get celebs updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
Meghan Markle has been pictured on a humanitarian visit to India – channeling Princess Diana. 
Prince Harry's girlfriend is campaigning for girls in developing countries to be given education about their periods in a bid to save their lives and prevent them from getting married too young. 
The actress dressed down for her charity work wearing a pair of skinny blue jeans with a loose-flowing top. 
And she wore a traditional bindi on her forehead just like Princess Diana did when she visited India in 1992 to support US aid organisation World Vision. Meghan Markle on a charity visit to India (Photo: worldvisioncan/Twitter) Princess Diana visited India in 1992 (Photo: Daily Mirror) 
Earlier this week, in a powerful essay for Time magazine, the Suits actress said her visit to India opened her eyes to the conditions teenage girls endure when they menstruate. 
A lack of toilets in schools and no access to sanitary protection – aside from old rags – means girls often drop out of education, or at least take time off school, which puts their development behind boys. Meghan has called for teenage girls in India to be given access to toilets and sanitary products (Photo: PA) 
The stigma and shame of having their period also means teenagers find it hard to talk about their bodies, even with their families. 
"With minimal dialogue about menstrual health hygiene either at school or home due to the taboo nature of the subject, many girls believe their bodies are purging evil spirits, or that they are injured once a month," Meghan pointed out. 
"This is a shame-filled reality they quietly endure. All of these factors perpetuate the cycle of poverty and stunt a young girl's dream for a more prolific future." Meghan, pictured with Prince Harry at a recent wedding, visited India in January (Photo: MEGA) 
She said that when young teens drop out of school, they can be at risk of being put to work in dangerous conditions to bring in income, and may be married off at too young an age. 
Meghan, 35, said girls need education about menstrual health hygiene, access to toilets and sanitary pads in order to change things, adding: "When we empower girls hungry for education, we cultivate women who are emboldened to effect change within their communities and globally. 
"If that is our dream for them, then the promise of it must begin with us. Period." 
The actress has been working with World Vision, the same charity that Harry's mum Princess Diana campaigned for. 
She had previously visited Afghanistan and Rwanda with the same NGO, working to improve the lives of children in third-world nations. 
She recently explained why she felt driven to champion worthy causes, saying: "While my life shifts from refugee camps to red carpets, I choose them both because these worlds can, in fact, coexist. And for me, they must. Meghan had previously visited Rwanda (Photo: Instagram) She "never wanted to be a lady who lunches" (Photo: Instagram/meghanmarkle) The actress has been working with the same charity Princess Diana supported (Photo: Instagram/meghanmarkle) 
"I never wanted to be a lady who lunches – I've always wanted to be a woman who works. And this type of work is what feeds my soul, and fuels my purpose." Read More
